title: Powder Granulation Techniques - Chemicals, Food and Drugs | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: Learn about granulation techniques used in the chemical, food, and pharmaceutical industries through lectures, hands-on laboratory projects, and demonstrations.

text_lines: Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
Powder Granulation Techniques - Chemicals, Food and Drugs
Powder Granulation Techniques - Chemicals, Food and Drugs
Learn about granulation techniques used in the chemical, food, and pharmaceutical industries through lectures, hands-on laboratory projects, and demonstrations.
Chemical Engineering, Food Technology, Pharmaceutical Engineering
This 2-day course is designed to give participants a comprehensive overview of granulation techniques for powder formulations used in the chemicals, food and pharmaceutical industries.

There will be lectures, hands-on laboratory projects and demonstrations to enable participants to apply theoretical knowledge from lectures to the actual preparation and evaluation of various formulations and their resultant granules. Granulation is extensively used in the food and pharmaceutical industries for the manufacturing of tablets and pellets. The production process is predictable and reproducible, enabling granules of consistent quality to be produced.
Manufacturing & production professionals in the pharmaceutical, nutraceutical, life sciences, flavours and fragrances and food industries
Diploma/degree in engineering or science or with relevant working experience
Basic understanding of chemistry (minimum ‘O’ Level or equivalent)
Granulation basics, technologies and optimisation techniques
Why granulation, dry and wet granulation technologies, granulation process parameters optimisation
High shear, fluidised bed, roller compaction
Particle size and shape, surface area, bulk and particle density, granule strength and friability, flow, moisture content, fines
Design, execute and document bench-scale studies to optimise appropriate operating parameters for obtaining quality granules
Associate Professor, Food, Chemical and Biotechnology, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor, Food, Chemical and Biotechnology, Singapore Institute of Technology

Reginald is a professional chemical engineer who specialises in surface science and understands the interfacial interactions of particulates in biological and materials systems. His overarching applied research goal will be to exploit the knowledge gained to design and fabricate novel ‘green’ composite materials for a variety of critical industry relevant applications. These include the areas of bioremediation, catalysis, carbon sequestration, drug delivery, energy, food technologies, water conservation and purification. He holds a US patent on using magnetic pollen grains as sorbents for removal of organic contaminants in water, and his work on particulate removal from surfaces using just water and heat (Leidenfrost effect) was featured in Nature Physics. He teaches in the Chemical Engineering and Food Technology cluster at SIT, and was previously a faculty at the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) and a visiting assistant professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). 
He holds a Bachelor of Science (Chemical Engineering) from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, a Master of Science (Chemical Engineering) and Doctor of Philosophy (Chemical Engineering) from the Georgia Institute of Technology.
Lead Professional Officer, Singapore Institute of Technology
Lead Professional Officer, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr. SK Mahasin Alam is a Lead Professional Officer at Singapore Institute of Technology, Singapore. His current research focuses on hydrogen safety - modelling of hydrogen dispersion (hydrogen concentration decay, accumulation of hydrogen in and enclosed environment, hydrogen plume dispersion length) and flame (visible flame length and width, radiative heat flux) characteristics. He obtained his PhD in computational chemistry from Nanyang Technological University, Singapore.

His research interests are Na and Li storage mechanisms, diffusion of Na and Li in organic batteries, and electronic properties and diffusion of dopants in doped semiconductors. He also focuses on the structural and electronic properties of Ge & Si nanowires and carbon nanotubes, interactions and reaction mechanisms of surface species on catalyst surfaces using the Density Functional Theory (DFT) method, and photoluminescence properties of graphene quantum dots and polymers using the time-dependent DFT method. Additionally, his interests include Quantitative Structure Activity Relationship studies of biomolecules for their bioactivities, molecular docking, and pharmacophore mapping.
A Certificate of Participation will be issued to participants who:
Undertake and pass non-credit bearing assessment during the course
The full fee for this course is S$1,744.00.
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.
Learn more about funding schemes available
There are no upcoming course runs at the moment.
Subscribe to our mailing list to learn about the latest dates as soon as they become available.
Towards Food Innovation, One Small Batch at a Time

Jointly launched by SIT, Enterprise Singapore and JTC in April 2022, FoodPlant, Singapore’s first shared facility for small-batch food production, has garnered interest from various food manufacturing players. One of them is SGProtein, a Singapore-based meat analogue manufacturer, who has partnered SIT and FoodPlant since 2021 through a series of student projects, Continuing Education & Training (CET) courses and manufacturing collaborations.
In a world shaped by constant disruption, lifelong learning is pivotal in nurturing innovative and adaptive workers, enhancing economic competitiveness and quality of life.
Explore the fundamentals of fire engineering science and its role in analysing fire behaviour, heat transfer, and fluid dynamics in complex built environments.
Graduate Certificate in Fire Dynamics and Fire Modelling
District Cooling Systems: Technologies, Components, and Sustainable Engineering
Learn the fundamentals of district cooling systems, including technologies, engineering principles, and sustainability strategies, to optimise efficiency and minimise environmental impact.
Sustainability, Energy Efficiency, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering
CHE6031N01 Process Safety Management and KPIs
Learn about effective Process Safety Management systems and associated performance measurement to ensure safe plant operations.
Graduate Certificate in Process Safety Management and Engineering Design
Next-Generation Food Innovation: Texture Development and Advanced Rheology
Learn theory in mechanics, rheology and biopolymer chemistry. Gain hands-on experience in extrusion basics and texturing a formulation using high-moisture or low-moisture extrusion.
CHE6031N02 Permit to Work for Management
This course delves into the operations and compliance measures of the Permit to Work (PTW) system, enhancing control over high-risk tasks and ensuring workplace safety.
Graduate Certificate in Process Safety Management and Engineering Design
This course covers RAM theory and its application across industries to assess system performance and efficiency, thereby enhancing system availability.
Graduate Certificate in Process Safety Management and Engineering Design

Jointly launched by SIT, Enterprise Singapore and JTC in April 2022, FoodPlant, Singapore’s first shared facility for small-batch food production, has garnered interest from various food manufacturing players. One of them is SGProtein, a Singapore-based meat analogue manufacturer, who has partnered SIT and FoodPlant since 2021 through a series of student projects, Continuing Education & Training (CET) courses and manufacturing collaborations.
